citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Fruit and vegetable crops for the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract:
This EnviroAtlas dataset includes data on the area, yield, and number of fruit and vegetable crops grown per 12-digit Hydrologic Unit (HUC) in the conterminous USA. The values are based on data from the United States Department of Agriculture's 2010 Cropland Data Layer (CDL).
This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose: This data can be used to find estimates of the amount and variety of fruits and vegetables grown in each 12-digit HUC. This information can provide insight into differences in access to locally grown produce across the United States. Users can visualize where in the US fruits and vegetables are most heavily produced, or find out how many different kinds of fruits or vegetables are grown near them. The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.
descript.supplinf:
Yield data was not available for every crop. Therefore, some crops that were counted toward fruit or vegetable crop area were not counted towards yields. This results in some 12-digit HUCs that show area used for growing fruits or vegetables, but either have no yields or low yields. The information in this dataset is an estimate based on the best available data, and should not be seen as a precise count or measurement of all crops in a HUC12.
This EnviroAtlas dataset is based on data originally developed using a version of the Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD 2011) extracted for EnviroAtlas on March 22, 2011. In 2015, EnviroAtlas transitioned from the WBD 2011 to a newer version - the National Hydrography Dataset Plus (NHDPlus) V2 WBD Snapshot, EnviroAtlas version - which includes updated 12-digit HUC boundaries for the Conterminous United States.
This EnviroAtlas dataset was created by reallocating the original WBD 2011 dataset to the NHDPlus V2 WBD Snapshot using area-weighted reallocation. The area weighting process assumes that values are distributed evenly across HUCs. In cases where values are unevenly distributed within a HUC, this can result in misallocated values in the new dataset. Therefore, users should exercise caution when interpreting this data, especially in regions where there are significant changes to the 12-digit HUCs. The majority of spatial changes between the two 12-digit HUC versions took place along the California coast, in Minnesota, and along the US-Canada border, especially in New England. Metric values for most of the rest of the United States are essentially unchanged. If the user is interested in data for a specific small area, especially in areas that were modified, using the original WBD 2011 version of this dataset joined with the WBD 2011 boundary feature class should provide accurate metric values. As new versions of the dataset are developed using the 2015 HUCs, these will replace the reallocated datasets in EnviroAtlas.
Before reallocating the metrics, edits were made to the area of some 12-digit HUCs. For example, along the coast of California some 12-digit HUCs had stopped at the coastline in the WBD 2011 dataset but were extended into the ocean in the NHDPlus V2 dataset. Instead of reallocating the metrics using the total area of the NHDPlus V2 HUCs, the land area based on National Land Cover Database (NLCD) 2011 was used to update the land area values. This ensured the land area of the NHDPlus V2 HUCs roughly matched the land area of the WBD 2011 HUCs. This method helped avoid incorrectly distributing terrestrial metrics, such as including the new ocean-extended area in the denominator of values that were originally calculated using land-only area as the denominator, which would result in artificially lowering the values of per-unit area metrics in the ocean-extended HUCs.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html

procstep.procdesc: Yield estimates by crop and state were obtained from the USDA county level 2010 National Agriculture Statistics Service (http://www.nass.usda.gov/). If a crop type did not have county-level yield data, state yields were used.
The yields were all converted to tons per Hectare.
USDA CDL Crop Data from 2010 was obtained for each state.

The yield estimates were added to the USDA crop data by adding 3 fields to the raster: Yield1 was used as the primary, Yield2 and Yield3 were added to track crop types that were in the yield table but not in the USDA data (usually subtypes like bell peppers vs chili peppers). Yield2 and Yield3 were only rarely used.
The USDA crop raster with yield values was broken down by HUC for each state; This gave a Hectare total and yield number per crop for each 12-digit HUC.
All 48 states were combined together. If a HUC crossed a state boundary, the areas were added together and the yields were averaged.
The data was then compressed into one dataset; In order to have just one record per HUC a large number of fields were needed. This was done by creating a set of fields for each crop type:
Added field "Yield1_XXX," where XXX is the CDL number of the crop: shows tons per hectare
Added field "Yield2_XXX," where XXX is the CDL number of the crop: shows tons per hectare
Added field "Yield3_XXX," where XXX is the CDL number of the crop: shows tons per hectare
Added field "AreaHa_XXX," where XXX is the CDL number of the crop: shows total area in Ha of the XXX CDL crop. This was found by counting the raster cells then converting to Ha.
Added field "Y1xHa_XXX," where XXX is the CDL number of the crop. Shows Yield1 field times the AreaHa field for each crop.
Added field "Y2xHa_XXX," where XXX is the CDL number of the crop. Shows Yield2 field times the AreaHa field for each crop. .
Added field "Y3xHa_XXX," where XXX is the CDL number of the crop. Shows Yield3 field times the AreaHa field for each crop.
Values for all fruit crop areas were summed to find the total area of fruit crops per 12-digit HUC.
Values for all vegetable crop areas were summed to find the total area of vegetable crops per 12-digit HUC.

The number of fruit crops by CDL number was counted for each 12-digit HUC to find the number of CDL fruit types grown per 12-digit HUC. Each CDL number occurring in a HUC was counted once under fruits, vegetables, or nuts.

The number of vegetable crops by CDL number was counted for each 12-digit HUC to find the number of CDL vegetable types grown per 12-digit HUC. The number of fruit crops by CDL number was counted for each 12-digit HUC to find the number of CDL fruit types grown per 12-digit HUC. Each CDL number occurring in a HUC was counted once under fruits, vegetables, or nuts.
Reallocated values from the original March 22 2011 WBD to the NHDPlus V2 WBD Snapshot, EnviroAtlas version for the Conterminous United States using area-weighted redistribution.

enttyp.enttypd: Counts, yields, and areas of fruit and vegetable crops by 12-digit HUC for the conterminous United States

attr.attrdef: The total area of land used to grow fruits per12-digit HUC, in hectares.
The total area of land used to grow vegetables per12-digit HUC, in hectares.
The number of CDL fruit crop types occuring in the 12-digit HUC
The number of CDL vegetable crop types occuring in the 12-digit HUC
The amount of fruit produced yearly in tons per 12-digit HUC.
The amount of vegetables produced yearly in tons per 12-digit HUC.
The amount of fruit produced yearly in thousands of tons per 12-digit HUC.
The amount of vegetables produced yearly in thousands of tons per 12-digit HUC.

overview.eaover:
This dataset includes a count of fruit and vegetable crops, total area of fruit and vegetable crops, and total yields for fruits and vegetables within each HUC.
Crops were categorized as fruits, vegetables, or nuts. Crops such as tomatoes were classified as vegetables based on their use. In the case of double crops: - lettuce/durum wheat, lettuce/cotton, and lettuce/barley were categorized as vegetables. - lettuce/cantaloupe was counted twice; it was added to both the fruit and vegetable count. Crops were categorized as follows: Fruits: Watermelons, Cherries, Peaches, Apples, Grapes, Citrus, Pears, Cantaloupes, Prunes, Oranges, Honeydew Melons, Pomegranates, Nectarines, Plums, Strawberries, Apricots, Blueberries, Cranberries. Vegetables: Sweet Corn, Mint, Sugarbeets, Potatoes, Sweet Potatoes, Onions, Cucumbers, Peas, Tomatoes, Hops, Herbs, Carrots, Asparagus, Garlic, Olives, Broccoli, Peppers, Squash, Lettuce, Pumpkins, Double Crop Lettuce/Durum Wheat, Double Crop Lettuce/Cotton, Double Crop Lettuce/Barley, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Celery, Radishes, Eggplants. Nuts: Almonds, Pistachios. Nuts did not appear often in the data, and they are not included in the final metrics.
Double Crop Lettuce/Cantaloupe was counted twice, once as a fruit and once as a vegetable.
Fruit and vegetable areas are the sums of the areas for all fruit or vegetable crops in each HUC12 in hectares.
Yields are in tons.
Yield data was not available for every crop. Therefore, some crops that were counted toward fruit or vegetable crop area were not counted towards yields. This results in some 12-digit HUCs that show area used for growing fruits or vegetables, but either have no yields or low yields. The information in this dataset is an estimate based on the best available data, and should not be seen as a precise count or measurement of all crops in a HUC12.
